trial_identification.studytitle: Prospective, open labelled, randomised daily wear trial comparing the ocular response and product performance between 1 Day Acuvue Moist, 1 Day Acuvue TruEye and Acuvue Oasys contact lenses in new and experienced wearers
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Prospective, open labelled, randomised daily wear trial comparing the ocular response and product performance between 1 Day Acuvue Moist, 1 Day Acuvue TruEye and Acuvue Oasys contact lenses in new and experienced wearers

interventions.interventions: Comparison of on eye performance of three marketed contact lenses used on a daily wear schedule. The contact lenses tested include 1 Day Acuvue Moist, 1 Day Acuvue Trueye and Acuvue Oasys. The trial will last for three months and the performance of the lenses on eye and subjective responses will be assessed.
interventions.comparator: There is no control group, all three lenses are tested and compared with each other

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary outcome: To evaluate the effect of lens wear on the ocular surface with 1 Day Acuvue Moist, 1 Day Acuvue TruEye and Acuvue Oasys by observing physiological variables including corneal staining.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At the baseline visit, 2 week, 1 month and 3 month visits

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Secondary outcome: To evaluate the on eye performance of 1 Day Acuvue Moist, 1 Day Acuvue TruEye and Acuvue Oasys by observing ocular physiological variables such as redness, contact lens variables such as lens fit and subjective variables with questionnaires.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At the baseline visit, 2 week, 1 month and 3 month visits

trial_design.sequence: Randomisation list will be generated from simple randomisation using randomisation computer software.

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Lvl 5, Rupert Myers Building (RMB), North Wing, Gate 14, Barker St, University of New South Wales (UNSW), Kensington 2052

ethicsAndSummary.summary: To observe on eye performance of three marketed contact lenses.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Vision Cooperative Research Centre and Institute for Eye Research Human Ethics
